title: 114_hr271
content: The Act may be cited as the "Creating Options for Veterans Expedited Recovery Act" or the "COVER Act". It establishes duties related to veterans' expedited recovery. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission is established to examine the efficacy of therapy for mental health illnesses in veterans and improve wellness outcomes. They will also conduct surveys to assess veterans' experiences with medical assistance for mental health issues within the Department of Veterans Affairs and non-Department facilities. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will examine the preferences and experiences of veterans with mental health treatments, including alternative therapies, medication prescriptions, and outreach efforts by the Secretary to promote available benefits and treatments. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will explore ways to improve mental health benefits and treatments for veterans, including researching complementary alternative therapies such as music therapy, equine therapy, service dog training, yoga therapy, acupuncture, meditation, outdoor sports therapy, hyperbaric oxygen therapy, and accelerated resolution therapy. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will study the potential increase of mental health claims from veterans of specific operations and assess the Department's resources to ensure timely delivery of quality healthcare for these claims. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will study mental health claims from veterans and assess resources for timely healthcare delivery. SEC. 3. MEMBERSHIP. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with at least one veteran in each group. Members must meet specific qualifications. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with at least one veteran in each group. Members must be individuals of recognized standing in the medical community with a background in treating mental health, have experience working with the military and veteran population, and not have a financial interest in any complementary alternative treatments reviewed by the Commission. The President designates a chairman, members are appointed for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and there is an appointment deadline. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission must appoint its members within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission must appoint its members within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of member appointments. Regular meetings will be called by the Chairman, which can be conducted using telecommunication technology. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and take necessary actions to fulfill its responsibilities. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission may gather information from nongovernmental organizations for guidance. The Commission is required to maintain accurate records of its actions and meetings, which are available for public inspection. Additionally, the Commission has the authority to request personnel from federal agencies on a reimbursable basis. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can request personnel from federal agencies to assist in its duties, with travel expenses covered. The Chairman can appoint staff without following typical government hiring procedures. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its duties as outlined in the Act. The executive director and personnel of the Commission are considered federal employees for specific purposes under title 5 of the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included in this classification. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can procure expert and consultant services, use postal services, and request physical facilities and equipment support from the Administrator of General Services to carry out its responsibilities under the Act. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can procure expert and consultant services, use postal services, and request physical facilities and equipment support from the Administrator of General Services to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. Administrative services may include human resource management, budget, leasing, accounting, and payroll services. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can request support from the Administrator of General Services to carry out its responsibilities under this Act, including expert services and physical facilities. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission must submit interim reports every 30 days detailing the cooperation received from the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and other government departments. These reports are to be sent to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives, the Senate, and the President. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will submit an interim report to the Senate and other entities, followed by a final report within 18 months. The final report will include recommendations for implementing solutions, an analysis of therapy models for mental health care, and the use of prescription drugs for treatment. The final report of the Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will include findings from a patient-centered survey, an examination of alternative treatments for mental health issues, and an action plan for implementing recommendations. The Commission will provide solutions and remedies to improve wellness-based outcomes for veterans with mental health issues, including a feasible timeframe for implementing alternative treatments Department-wide. The Secretary will justify any recommendations deemed not feasible and provide alternative solutions to enhance therapy efficacy for treating veterans. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report under section 5(b).
